issue.title: Refactoring Stacking, Multiplexer, Ensembler and TransformedTarget Forecasters

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Reference : https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/955

-- This is a copy of 965 without changes to reducer.py (a time when there was no bug)
We need to slowly re-factor all forecasters to be compliant with the new interface (see PR #912). i.e., no overrides of fit etc and descendant classes only implementing core logic, while the BaseForecaster implements check etc logic.

Currently this is running due to various downwards compatibility workarounds, which should be removed once all forecasters are ready (in "no-override" state)

The forecasters that still need a downstream refactor are:

  
- [x] EnsembleForecaster
- [x] MultiplexForecaster
- [x] TransformedTargetForecaster
- [x] StackingForecaster

body:
From #977:

> A few thoughts:
> * I see tags as being defined on the class (not object) level, conceptually I think of them as describing algorithm properties, so I would prefer not to update them dynamically
> * In the cases of the above mentioned (composition) algorithms, for the implementation (i.e. input validation of the forecasting horizon), the tag should be set to False, the composite doesn't require the forecasting horizon during fitting, it merely passes it on to the components, which have their own tag and raise an error accordingly if they require the forecasting horizon during fitting
> * For documentation, when users may use tags for finding relevant models, setting it to False may be misleading, but conceptually still makes sense, as it refers to the composition algorithm, rather than a particular instance of the composite

>I see tags as being defined on the class (not object) level, conceptually I think of them as describing algorithm properties, so I would prefer not to update them dynamically

Yes, but do you see the problem? The properties of composites may depend on components.
Especially in pipelines this is important, so it would be good if there is something like a "dynamic tag".
At least, it should be settable or overridable at construction.

>the tag should be set to False, the composite doesn't require the forecasting horizon during fitting, it merely passes it on to the components, which have their own tag and raise an error accordingly if they require the forecasting horizon during fitting

disagreed!

I think each forecaster should be able to tell the user in advance whether it will raise an error when no `fh` is passed to fit. What else is the purpose of these tags? That's also what you are testing for.

Now the stage at which the forecaster should be able to tell that is up for discussion though, i.m.o - my preference would be when constructed, i.e., as an object.

the problem I have with the tags in scikit learn is they are not inherited, but rather shadowed for each subclass, due to multiple inheritance. This means checking tags requires a recursive call up the inheritance hierarchy. This is hideous imo. We could use tags, but we need to be able to recover the values in the base class fit if we move to fit/_fit, so we will need inheritance and overriding to make that work, or to use this ludicrous programming pattern. I'm not even sure that dynamic binding even works properly/how I would expect it to in python, I need to check, I dont trust this language

issue.title: ForecastingPipeline for pipelining with exog data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Enhancement proposal: https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/01_forecasting_api/forecasting_pipeline.md

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
ForecastingPipeline for pipelining with exog data

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

1. Inheritance from new class `_Pipeline`
2. There is an issue to use the `ForecastingPipeline` just for the purpose of a transformer pipeline, bcz in the transformer interface, we allow in `transform(Z, X)` that `Z` can be a `pd.DataFrame` but in the `fit(y, X)` function `y` must be a `pd.Series`. Solutions for this which I have considered:
    1)  It would only be allowed to use `ForecastingPipeline` as a transformer pipeline if `y` and `X` are given like `fit_transform(y, X)`. This is the status when I open this PR.
    2)  We could add an if-statement in `fit()` to catch cases where `y` is a `pd.DataFrame`, however this would be an impact to the interface that we allow `y` to be a `pd.DataFrame` which is never the case so far. 
    3) We dont implement `transform()` for `ForecastingPipeline`

General question of using `ForecastingPipeline` or `TranformedTargetForecaster` as a transformer pipeline: when calling `fit_transform`, the `fit` and `transform` functions are called and this means that also the given `forecaster` is fitted. So also a forecaster has to be given, but we might want to allow `forecaster=None`. This might probably best be done in a separate PR.

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [x] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
___
Martin Walter <martin_friedrich.walter@daimler.com>, Mercedes-Benz AG on behalf of Daimler TSS GmbH.
https://github.com/Daimler/daimler-foss/blob/master/LEGAL_IMPRINT.md

body: the utility function `_all_tags` that @mloning wrote mimicks nested inheritance, and it's a capability that's reatively easily supplemented. This might just as easily be turned into a python getter.

>where is that method

in `sktime.base._base.BaseEstimator`, to be refactored and moved into `BaseObject` in #877/#891

this also raises another issue, why not use scikit learn tags? I believe this code is cloned from scikit
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/122684620-4f768d80-d1fe-11eb-9790-418b1d2183ce.png)

I realise its not a strong argument, but I object to this on aesthetic grounds. If I want to query whether a classifier has a capability, I have to iterate over the whole inheritance hierarchy, build a new one off data structure of the tags, then query that data structure. I cannot buy into such horrible, inefficient design  when a much simpler, clearer system is available.

>If I want to query whether a classifier has a capability, I have to iterate over the whole inheritance hierarchy, build a new one off data structure of the tags, then query that data structure. I cannot buy into such horrible, inefficient design when a much simpler, clearer system is available.

what is the simpler system? This is simply inheritance of nested attributes, quite simple (but not out-of-the-box in python)

What I would propose is that we have two annotaitons:

* class tags, for the general class functionality - this is "worst case" properties
* object tags - these are created upon construction. The new `get_tags` method looks for class tags first, then overrides these with any object tags that were created in `__init__`, dependent on parameter settings.

if it were using inheritance normally it would not have to traverse the inheritance hierarchy, you could just query the data structure directly because it has been, you know, inherited. Also, I dont like random free form string tags, I prefer boolean variables. The simpler system (imo) is the one we currently use for classifiers, where capabilities are declared in the classifier and passed to the check function. I don't want to abandon this just yet, particularunless we are going to use the same tags as scikit learn, as it all seems a bit unnecessary to me and only justifiable for scikit compliance.

the problem is, you want the set of capabilities/tags inspectable - and for that it seems the only good solution is have them in a list/dict, as opposed to as general attributes - note that attributes can be anything, not just tags, so it is not explicitly inspectable which attributes are tags or not.
design anti-pattern: "secret" knowledge, i.e., the information is only decodable if you know undocumented conventions. `get_tags` or similar does not require such undocumented conventions.

So here is an interesting question, @TonyBagnall: are all sensible tags that we expect capabilities?
I.e., related to properties or scitype aspects of the estimator?

E.g., a tag that tells interface counterparts what the internal data representation used is (np.array or pd.DataFrame) is not a "capability" in a narrow sense, right?

In this case, should we have a hyper-tag that tells us whether a tag is a capability?

issue.title: Auto-generate a classifier Capabilities summary

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
task is to auto generate a table of Capabilities like this

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/996

and to get it to automatically display on sktime.org (we can help with this stage)

body:
@mloning, @TonyBagnall, any opinions about "class tags", and "object tags" that can override "class tags" at construction?
With the override happening in `_all_tags`.

I'm not that sure how static variables work in python, but I believe our capabilities are static. However, we are not necessarily using them as static variables! I'll have a look

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/68645/are-static-class-variables-possible-in-python

personally, I prefer boolean variables to free form string tags, but thats probably just me

>I'm not that sure how static variables work in python, but I believe our capabilities are static. However, we are not necessarily using them as static variables

The problem is that the capabilities ("scientific" properties) are not necessarily static, they may depend on hyper-parameters and components.
This is rare for "primitive type" hyper-parameters, but the typical case for complex hyper-parameters or estimator components.

So in my opinion we need a way to set, or at least override, them at construction and perhaps even at any parameter setting that happens (the latter may be overkill).

Regarding boolean variables: I think we need more, since some tags are a way to get scityping.
See, e.g., PR #980 and #1013 which I feel would be unnecessarily complicated by insisting on boolean tags - we would have to laboriously "decode" multiple boolean tags into one of multiple types or strings.

I'm not militant about this, so if its changed then I wont complain... 

However, my view is that capabilities relate to the functionality of the class. So if say unequal_length == true, an object of this class is capable of taking as input unequal class values and is safe to build with data having that characteristic. There may be many ways a class can deal with a data characteristic, and there may be an object variable that can determine that and be set in the constructor. However, the capabilities are simply for error checking: if you pass a certain type of data and it will crash the algorithm, it should throw a meaningful exception. Configuring capabilities doesn't make sense to me, that should require new code. Having capabilities declared at the class value makes it very easy to see what a class can do. However, it may screw up the _fit/fit model assuming the point of that is to generalise the checks before overloaded _fit() is called, I'm not sure how python handles this kind of polymorphism.

>So if say unequal_length == true, an object of this class is capable of taking as input unequal class values and is safe to build with data having that characteristic

Yes, but please consider what I'm saying.

Whether unequal class values can be dealt with an object, may depend on the parameters and components of that object. Consider a pipeline with transformers and a classifier at the end. An object of the "pipeline" type will be able to deal with that data if and only if the classifier at the end can.

This (logically) shows that the (scientific/logical) property cannot be a property of the class, but is in fact a property of the object with given parameters.

From a user/query perspective, one may want to distinguish "always" and "sometimes" as a class property.

@fkiraly could you write down what you think the main reasons are for having object-level tags (e.g. tags updated dynamically depending on components) rather than static class-level tags? I think is related to how we want to use tags.
